dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A small New York City apartment, sparsely furnished. MIRA PRESLEY, 21, sits on the floor amid moving boxes and suit packing to move out. She@s sorting through a stack of old record albums, through them as she piles them in a box. We catch sight of some relics from t era as well as several classic country albums - Donny Osmond and the @Saturday N Fever@В® soundtrack mixed in with Patsy Cline and Hank Williams and Elvis. Af brief look, she piles them in a box and closes the lid. She looks outside her w and sees the sun coming up; she@s been up all night. Miranda goes over to the window and opens it. It@s barely out, but already the sound of someone@s radio filters in. We hear a car alarm in the distance. Miranda drags a large, full trash bag over to the window, down, and heaves it out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The trash bag falls from a fifth-floor window and into a overflowing with about ten huge trash bags; Miranda@s thrown out a lot of The garbage truck arrives just as the bag lands in the dumpster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun@s all the way up now. It@s a bright June morning. teenage boys sit on the stoop next to Miranda@s building. They have a boom box, a hear loud street music. Miranda comes out of her building carrying a movin She wears Levi@s cut off mid-thigh, sneakers, and a black leather jacket over shirt. She carries the box down the front steps and drops it on a pile on the si front of a waiting cab. The cab driver just leans against his car, watching her

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You know what would be great? If you could just stand there, watching me carry all these boxes out by myself. Don@t carry out any yourself, don@t hold the door for me, and whatever you do, don@t put them in your cab. And if you could possible start the meter running now. She leans over and peers into the cab. The meter@s runnin smiles at the cab driver, who doesn@t seem to understand English.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Perfect. Good job. Thank you. She gives him a thumbs up. He smiles and gives her one ba She goes back for another box

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the cab parked in from of a luxury high-rise apart building. The cab driver leans again the car, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, expensively furnished apartment. Miranda@s boxes piled in the hallway. ELLEN DALY, 43, and immaculately dressed socialite, looks mild distaste at the boxes cluttering her hallway.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I just never imagined there would be this much, Miranda. Miranda stands in the living room, looking at pictures of a family that doesn@t include Miranda - a respectable, clean-cut husband and tw little boys. There is one small picture of Miranda; she looks like she@s still school.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You should see how much I threw out. Ellen walks in and sits on the couch. She sits formally; doesn@t exactly radiate warmth. Miranda turns away from the photos.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You can ship them to me as soon as I get an apartment.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Maybe I should keep them in storage until you come back.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m not coming back. Ellen looks at her like she doesn@t believe her, but she@ along.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Mom, I told you, I@m moving. Ellen occupies her hands by compulsively straightening th her coffee table, which were already pretty straight.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Saying you@re going to do something and actually doing it are two entirely different things. I hate to see you give up everything to go and pursue this fantasy you have about being a... . country singer. Have you taken a moment to stop and look at your behavior?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@11 do it on the bus, O.K.? Ellen assumes the role of the voice of reason.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I know you father made Nashville sound very romantic. I wish he were here now to see you acting this way. He could tell you how difficult it is.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: That@s not what he@d tell me.  (sadly, remembering) Daddy would tell me I can anything in the world.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: Yes, he probably would, but in the real world, the chances of making it are a million to one.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How can I pass up a one in a million opportunity? She smiles. Ellen doesn@t.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t expect you to understand why I have to do this. I just want you to send me my stuff.

dialogues.speaker: ELLEN
dialogues.text: I really think you should think about this for a few days.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (determined) I@ve been thinking about it my whole life. It@s time for me to do it. Miranda@s saying this more for her own benefit; her mothe seem to be listening.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I have to go. My cab is waiting. She goes to her mother and kisses her on the cheek.

dialogues.speaker: APARTMENT BUILDING
dialogues.text: Miranda comes out of the building and crosses the sidewal cab. She talks to the driver, not expecting him to understand

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: My mother thinks she can control my life. Surprisingly, the driver speaks, with a heavy foreign acc

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She stills sees you as a little girl. Miranda looks only mildly surprised that the driver has u everything she has said. She gets in the cab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We hear a simple country ballad. A Greyhound bus travels the mountains.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sits in a window seat, asleep, resting her head a her jacket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda@s in the same seat, awake now, staring out the wi the darkness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bus is making a rest stop. (We see that the destinati reads @Nashville@.) Passengers walk around, stretching their legs. Miranda le against a wall, checking her watch, impatient.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We still hear the country music. Miranda comes into the t carrying a huge suitcase and a guitar. She squints at the light, reaches jacket pocket, pulls out her sunglasses and puts them on. She looks around. Aman i cowboy hat sits on a bench. He gives Miranda a friendly smile and an almost ti hat. She looks at him like she@В®s trying to figure out what species he is her stuff outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda looks around and spots a taxi across the street. her index and middle fingers inside her mouth of whistles. Everyone within ear turns and looks at her.  The taxi driver looks up from his newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda gets in the back of the cab. The driver closes th and gets in front.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Where to? Miranda hands him a newspaper clipping.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Do you know where this is? Lucy@s Caf@?

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: They@d have to take away my license if I didn@t. He starts to drive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close on a guitar case. Then another, and another, separa a row of blue-jeaned knees and cowboy boots. Now we see faces, some young, some not-so-young, some hop some weary. All are patient, lined up against a brick wall, an incongruou at any mini-mall but this one.

dialogues.speaker: FEMALE VOICE, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: O.K. Listen up. Gentlemen, ladies. Everyone in line quiets down. They turn their attention t JENKINS, 30@s, the owner of Lucy@s Caf@.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: As you go in, make sure you take an application. No one tries out without filling one of these out. Hurry it up, doors close at 3:05. Anyone not inside by 3:05 gets locked out. Lucy goes back inside. The line files in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver turns to talk to Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: You a songwriter?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: Lucky for you. Town@s full of them. 1@n a songwriter myself.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m a singer. The driver reacts to this silently; she@s not lucky after

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A cozy restaurant with small tables, country music memora the walls, and a small stage. Lucy stand on the stage with a stack of completed applica her hand.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Thank you all for coming today. When I call your name, come right up on stage. Pretend like you@re in a hurry, we got all day but there@s a lot of people want to be famous here. If it@s your first time here, you should know: if you don@t pass, it just means I don@t think you@re ready. Go home and keep at it and come back again. Don@t give up unless you can@t stand to listen to your own material. All right, let@s get to it. Lucy looks at the first application.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Cash Wilneck, get on up here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The driver hands the clipping back to Miranda. She takes moves her hand in the  air over the back of the driver@s seat.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Where@s the safety glass? He glances over his shoulder at her; what safety glass?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I could shoot you if I wanted. This is an observation, not a threat.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: (smiles) Appreciate it if you didn@t.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A young man takes the stage, sits on the stool and begins a mediocre country ballad, slightly out of tune.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, carrying her guitar in one hand and her suitcase other, gets out of the cab and heads for the entrance of Lucy@s At the same time, JAMES WYNN, 23, gets out of his pick-up Lucy@s parking lot. James is good-looking in a somewhat dangerous way. H picks up his guitar case and strides over to Lucy@s, getting there just before Mir tries the door. It@s locked.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It@s locked? James looks at her, the way she@s dressed, the huge suitc carries. He looks amused.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Was your bus late? She gives him the same attitude back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Well, it@s a long way from... New York City.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yes it is. Who are you? The psychic welcoming committee?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: James Wynn. The door is locked.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Miranda Presley. T@11l just knock. She goes up to the door.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No, don@t. Lucy doesn@t let anyone in late. That@ll set me back a month. We@ll have to get in some other way.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m sure there@s a secret underground tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Another young songwriter auditions. This one plays the fi has a friend backing him up on guitar. He@s energetic, but the song isn@t very Lucy sits in the back of the crowded room. She reveals no expression as she watches the songwriter, but we see her head shake @no@В® slightly makes a notation on his application and places it in what is presumably the rejec

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sits on the sidewalk outside the caf@. James lock suitcase in his truck and comes and sits down next to her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe someone will come out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: There@1ll be a lot of people coming out in about two hours.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Did I mention that I can vaporize myself like @I Dream of Jeannie@?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: A lot of good that does me. They sit there a moment.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I have an idea. Let@s knock.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It@s true. Everyone is slower down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onstage, a woman with teased blond hair, fringed cowboy s and matching white cowboy hat and boots, stands with her guitar, dancing aro she sings off-key.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda knocks quietly on the door. No answer. She knocks little louder. The door opens. She gives James a look. A face appears from i it belongs to LINDA LUE LINDEN, 20, a sweetly attractive Southern belle puts her finger to her lips and lets them in. The blond woman finishes and steps off the stage. Lucy ca the next name.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Nick Reynolds. NICK REYNOLDS, early 30@s, gets up to and goes to the sta James and Miranda sit down with Linda Lue at a table near the door. Linda L some blank applications on the next table and hands them to James an Nick takes the stage. He wears a baseball cap with a tru company logo. He sits at the microphone and addresses the room.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Hi, I@m Nick Reynolds. I@m from Memphis, originally. This one@s called @Shoot me up, run me down, take me back,@ and it@s dedicated to you, Lucy. Lucy seems unmoved by the sentiment. A few auditioners sm knowingly. Nick starts to play. He seemed like a pretty soft-spoken guy u now, but he was apparently saving his personality for his performance. Th is humorous, about cartoonishly extreme devotions to a woman who won@t pay h attention. Nick@В®s fellow musicians are a good audience, laughing in the app places. Lucy doesn@t laugh at the song; she matter-of-factly move application into the @yes@ pile.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Next. Linda Lue Linden. We see Lucy look up, amused.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Goodness, honey, is that your name? Linda Lue hurries toward the stage.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I@m afraid so. (smiling, into the microphone) Hi, I@m Linda Lue, from Briar Hill, Alabama. I jut finished this one, it@s called @Heaven knocked on my door.@ Linda Lue starts her song; she has a sweet voice, but it@ Her song is cute, using silly metaphors. She@s not awful, but she@s not esp good, either.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Onstage, a young singer, eyes closed beneath his cowboy h a heartfelt ballad. He@s pretty good. While he@s performing, James takes his Miranda@s completed applications over to Lucy@s table. He presents them confi as if he has no doubt she@ll accept them. Lucy raises any eyebrow at him, but t applications.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: KYLE DAVIDSON, 22, sits on the stool. He@s clean cut, wea jeans and boots, but no hat. He looks a little jumpy.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I@m, um, Kyle Davidson. I@m from Texas. (laughs nervously) I@m a little nervous, but it doesn@t really show. Kyle clears his throat and stares at the floor.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: This song is called @Blue and Blue.В® Kyle seems to be more than just a little nervous; he bare manages to raise his head high enough to sing into the mike. He sings without confi his voice cracking. The songs sounds like it might actually be good if he was butchering it. Lucy stares at Kyle, deep in thought, holding his application. Mirand him too, listening closely to his song.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Lucy@s down to the last two applications. She calls James out, an edge in her voice.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: James Wynn James gets up and picks up his guitar. He strides up and the stool. He looks straight out at the audience and introduces himself. His manner is folksy.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Howdy. James Wynn, from Austin, Texas. I call this one @Friends no more.В® He strums the guitar and starts to sing. His voice is str and he@s a charismatic performer. His song is great too (a ballad, e.g. @lIt Onl Me When I Cry@). The audience is drawn into his performance.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: Lucy holds the last application.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Miranda Presley, looks like you get to be the fat lady. Miranda takes the stage. She looks good. Not too nervous.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Hi, I@m Miranda Presley from New York City. She starts to play. She didn@t mention the name of her so that@s all right because we already know this song. It@s @Desperado. Miranda close her eyes as she starts the lyrics She has a beautiful voice, very distinctive, and the song sounds great. Just as she finishes the first verse, we hear:

dialogues.speaker: LUCY, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Excuse me. Excuse me. Miranda? Honey, do you have another song? Miranda smiles, rolling with the punches.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Sure. I know lots of songs. What do you want to hear?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Try something I haven@t heard before. A Miranda Presley composition, maybe. This ain@t @Star SearchВ®.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Oh. Well, I don@t have anything right now. Lucy picks up her pile of applications and approaches the Auditions are over.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Well, come on back when you do, 0O.K.? Miranda hops off the stage, spirit intact.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Sure thing. Lucy shakes her head in wonder at the girl and walks up t microphone.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Now. I@m going to read off the names of the people who passed for next month@s performances. If I read your name, come see me to sign up for which night you want to play. Nancy Butterworth, Nick Reynolds, Tom Mortenson, Ricky Hogan, James Wynn.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Miranda stand next to his truck. He opens the p door and takes out her suitcase. He sets it on the ground. She looks disappo she doesn@t know where she@s going to go now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You want a lift somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Why, I would be much obliges if you would convey me in this Glen Campbell Hee-Haw pick-up truck. James picks up the suitcase and tosses it in the back of

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Just so you know, I@m not taking this personally, these little jabs and put- downs about what a yee-haw hillbilly town you have landed your cosmopolitan self in. Where are you staying?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I haven@t decided. Miranda sees Linda Lue crossing the parking lot next to h calls to her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Linda Lue Linden. Linda Lue turns around. She looks pleased to be noticed, comes over.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Thanks for sneaking us in.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Oh, you@re welcome. I don@t normally flaunt the rules, but my little voice told me I should open that door. And I do believe it was right. (to James) You were real good. You got a lot of presence up there. Some people, they sing real good, but they got no presence, you know?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Thanks. One of the singers approaches; his truck is parked next t We recognize him as Kyle, the one with stage fright. He notices James.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: James, right? Kyle Davidson. They shake hands

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Nice job tonight. First time?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (nods) First week in town.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (to Kyle) Did you make it? He seems a little startled by her directness.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Too bad. I liked your song. He looks at her skeptically; is she making fun of him?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Yeah, I liked yours too. Always have. She laughs, then starts to sing Kyle@s song a cappella. I didn@t know it before, we now know it@s a beautiful song. She sings just the first and stops. Kyle stares at her, drawn into her singing, hearing his song the way it be. Even after she stops, he stares at her. Finally, he grins.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: That@s it exactly. How did you know that? Miranda doesn@t see what he@s so excited about.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: All I did was sing it on key.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Are you going to Red@s? A bunch of us are going to Red@s. For a beer. Kyle looks like it@s important to him that she goes.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: That sounds like fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (to James) Are you going?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I am.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (to Kyle) See you there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, James, Kyle and Linda Lue sit together at a tabl see quite a few familiar faces from Lucy@s audition at surrounding tables. Everyon bottle of beer except for Linda Lue, who drinks a Shirley Temple.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (to Linda Lue) Don@t even tell me; you have least. three relatives who have died of consumption. Linda Lue seems pleased with Miranda@s accuracy.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well, it@s four if you count Eddie. He was my mother@s second cousin on her mother@s side. He was found at the bottom of my inflatable play pool. I found him, actually.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (Whispering, to James) The bottom of the pool? Linda Lue goes on cheerfully, oblivious of the stunned re

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I noticed you have your suitcase. Do you have a place to stay? Miranda just looks at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a real cute motel room, with two beds. There@s even a pool, shaped like a guitar. We could share it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (To Miranda, pointedly) She has a pool.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@ve known me fifteen minutes and you want me to move in? I could be a serial killer, for all you know.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Oh, I can see that you@re not. I@m an excellent judge of character. I@ve got a touch of the power. Miranda doesn@t want to ask what the power is.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: My grandmother can tell when a tornado is coming, a week in advance. Linda Lue nods; she knows exactly what he means.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Some things are beyond our comprehension. (to Kyle) Let me see your palm. He gives it to her.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Now you, you got a real strong heart line, see it here.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Is that good?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well, sure, but it can also be a little dangerous. My cousin Lester, he had a similar heart line, and he threw himself in front of a speeding train in the name  of love. Miranda smirks.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: My cousin Leon did the very same thing.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Isn@t that a coincidence. You want me to do yours? Linda Lue reaches for Miranda@s hand. Miranda drops the p and lets her have it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: If I1@m going to meet with a bizarre premature death, I@d just as soon not know about it Linda Lue looks up from Miranda@s palm and answers her gr

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: All right. (looking at Miranda@s hand) Oh, well I envy you this life line. You@re going to make your mark. People will remember you when you@re gone. Miranda pulls her hand back.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I@m not saying it@1ll be soon. Don@t you want me to read your heart line? Miranda doesn@t offer her hand.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hey, let me see your heart line. Miranda holds out her hand. James pretends to examine it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You will remain unmarried until the age of 60 . . . at which time you will wed a series  of men with one common characteristic.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Namely? He squints at her palm.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: They will all be named Bubba. Sometimes it will be a nickname, or a middle name. Miranda carefully extracts her hand from James@В®. He loo suggestively, as if she@s fighting the impulse to jump him. She answers with real@ look. The music on the jukebox has stopped. Miranda reaches for guitar. She starts to play a song. James watches her, hears the opening chords, reaches for his guitar. James starts playing the same song as Miranda, @I don@t k you don@t want me.@ Miranda begins to sing.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (singing) It@s the right time, and though I feel fine tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (singing) I don@t know why you don@t want me

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (singing) It@s the right place, IZ@ve got the new face tonight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (singing) I don@t know why you don@t want me. Kyle and Linda Lue join in. Soon the other hopefuls from audition are singing along, commiserating abut their rejection.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda Lue has apparently had a hand in the decorating of it@s hard to believe the motel provided matching floral chintz drapes, bedspre pillows, or a framed photo of Loretta Lynn. Linda Lue@s dog, of the tiny furry variety, sits on his own floral pillow. Miranda throws her suitcase on one of

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: You can have either bed. I@ve been using this one She points to the one Miranda has not chosen.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: but you can take whichever you want. Miranda leaves her suitcase where it is and looks around. are several stacks of Bibles in the room. She lifts the cover of one, verifying it is, and decides not to deal with this information.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Is this the extra, the Loretta Lynn suite? She flops down on the bed, her eyes closed. Linda Lue@s d comes over and sniffs Miranda, then settles in next to her. Miranda opens her e sees the dog, and closes them again. The phone rings. Linda Lue picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: (into phone) Hello? Hi, Mama. . . Well, I just got in this second, Mama. . . Things are real good. Linda Lue sits up straight, her right hand flat on her be Without looking down, she crosses her fingers, first on her right hand, then on her the one holding the phone.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Uh-huh. (brightly)  I passed my audition. Miranda@s eyes open; she tilts her head back and looks at Lue upside down. She@s surprised at the lie but, then again, she really do give a shit. Miranda gets up and opens her suitcase. She takes out a pair of jeans.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well, I was waiting for you take a breath, Mama, so I could get a word in. Yeah, just like Loretta. Linda Lue rolls her eyes at Miranda, who@s changing into

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Only prettier. Miranda smiles. She pulls a black leather-bound notebook her suitcase and picks up her guitar. Linda Lue covers the mouthpiece with her h

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Are you going somewhere?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m just going to go to that coffee shop across the street. She takes her motel room key off the table and puts it on around her neck, next to several other keys and a locket.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: But it@s late. Don@t you want to go to bed?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m not tired. I@11l be quiet when I come in. Linda Lue is perplexed.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well, all right. I@11 be seeing you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Scarlett.  Miranda leaves.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: (into phone) I@m listening, Mama. Who died? Well, what was it that killed him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda is settled into a booth, a full cup of coffee in her, circling classifieds in a newspaper. She doesn@t seem to be finding too much. Lin enters the coffee shop, wearing a frilly pink robe over flowered pajamas wi and furry bedroom slippers. Her hair is pulled back with a pink band. She l like an exceptionally tall five-year-old. She spots Miranda and pads over to her tab Miranda looks at her and puts down her paper.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Did I remember to give the spare room key?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Annette, I@ve got a hot tip that Frankie and his friends are going to crash your slumber party. You don@t want to miss that. Linda Lue sits down across from her.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Do you hate me?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How could anyone possibly hate you? You@re Miss Congeniality.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I was hoping we could be great friends.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t know if that@s such a fabulous idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not? Miranda glances down at Linda Lue@s foot, which sticks ou under the table.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (noticing) Your pajamas have feet. Linda Lue waits for an answer.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Look, I came here to be alone. Nothing personal. Linda Lue looks hurt. Miranda smiles at her kindly.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Nothing personal. I swear. Cross my heart. Linda Lue draws herself up and speaks with conviction.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Some people aren@t exactly the people you they are when you first meet someone. She gets up and pads out of the coffee shop. Miranda watc go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The sun@s just coming up. Miranda@s still in her booth, h head resting on her arm, asleep. The waitress comes up with a pot of coffee and to her on the arm.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: More coffee, honey? Miranda looks up, then out the window, squinting at the s

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No, thanks. The waitress leaves. Miranda puts a couple dollars on th picks up her stuff, and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda enters the darkened motel room. The mess she left been cleaned up; apparently Linda Lue unpacked for her. Miranda pulls off jeans, removes her bra without taking off her t-shirt, and crawls into bed. Meanwhile, in the other bed, Linda Lue opens her eyes, se Miranda, and stretches. She gets out of bed, picks up her robe and goes to the ba The dog jumps off Linda Lue@s bed and goes to sleep with Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda@s still in bed, asleep. The air conditioner hums. There@s a knock on the door. Miranda reaches for the clock; it@s 3:10. She gets out of walks over to the dresser. She opens a drawer, finds a pair of boxer shorts puts them on. Another knock.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Who@s here at this ungodly hour? She opens the door. It@s Kyle, holding his guitar. She lo out at him sleepily, her hair a mess, pillow marks on her face. The dog stands at feet.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Hi. You look good.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What are you, getting ready to go out? The dog growls at Kyle.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m thinking there@s some reason you@re here.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I just saw Linda Lue. She said you@d be asleep. He looks at the dog, who continues a low growl.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Thanks. Let me know if she says anything else. She starts to close the door.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Wait. I wanted to ask you something. She open the door again. The dog steps up the growl.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Is that your dog? She looks at him; of course it@s not her dog.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: That@s not my question. Will you help me with my singing?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Is that your question?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: That@s it.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (smiles) Yeah?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Now? She nods, tolerant of his excitement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I@11 even make you dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. She closes the door. The dog stops growling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle and Miranda sit in beach chairs on the roof of his a building, with their guitars. There@s a grill next to Kyle; he@s barbequeing something for dinner. Kyle@s finishing up a song, a beautiful ballad (e.g. @Kee from blowing away@). His voice is tentative, and he watches his fingers as he

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: All right. Now start the song again, but instead of singing, tell me about your guitar. Kyle starts to strum the chords to the song.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What do you want to know about it?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t know, some kind of amusing anecdote about how your daddy traded a pig for it, or the ghost of Hank Williams Sr. Left it on your front porch. Kyle has started to watch his fingers again. He looks up, decides not to let her get to him.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: My mom gave me this guitar. She said she could tell I had a lot of creative energy.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What about your dad?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I don@t know, what about him?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Anything. Keep playing.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: The first time I came to Nashville, I was here four months before I ran out of money and had to turn around and come back home. I thought he@d want me to give it up, since I hadn@t made it. But he just put me back to work on the ranch. Said he could use me until I was ready to give it another go.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Letting life teach you its own lessons, realizing your dreams weren@t the same as his dreams. Kyle laughs.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Stop me if you@ve heard my life story before.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I saw that episode of Gunsmoke. Anyway, the important thing is you@re playing the guitar without looking at your fingers. He stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Of course I don@t have to watch my fingers. It@s part of my style.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Well, don@t do it anymore. Now, look at me and sing some of the words. Kyle starts to play again, looking Miranda in the eye. He and starts the song over. He opens his mouth, then shuts it again. Finally, h stops playing.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I can@t do it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: It@s personal. It@s part of me. You and me, here alone, my singing to you is practically like stripping down naked. Miranda raises her eyebrows, as if he might actually disr

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Isn@t it like that for you, singing one of your songs?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It seems to me that this is a rather serious handicap for an aspiring performer.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I don@t want to be a performer. I@d have to be insane to think I could ever make a dime with this voice.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I thought you wanted to learn to sing.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I do. So I can sing on writer@s night. I can@t get my songs recorded if nobody hears them.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Is that the only way to get them heard?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I@ve done about a hundred demos, me songs with other singers. Vince Gill put a song of mine on hold last summer, was thinking about putting it on his new album, but he didn@t end up cutting it. Miranda picks up her guitar.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe if you see yourself as an actor, like it@s not really you. Play the  part in the song. She starts to strum a few chords. She looks Kyle in the e she sings, acting as if the words were meant for him. The sun is setting behind h

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (singing) I loved you yesterday And I love you just the same And none of the things you do Could tear us apart I loved you yesterday And I love you just the same When I gave myself to you You took only my heart She puts the guitar down. Kyle fell for the act; he slightly lovestruck.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: That@s nice. You write that?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (shakes her head no) Lyle Lovett. He@s my favorite.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You@re not proving your point until you play me one of your songs. He gets up to check on the barbeque.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: One of what? She smiles at him; she doesn@t have any songs.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You haven@t written any songs?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re a songwriter. I@m a singer.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You just haven@t written any songs yet. Nobody moves from New York to Nashville to be a singer. looks

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody but me. Kyle shakes his head no.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Country music@s all about the words, having something to say. You wouldn@t be here if you didn@t have those words inside you. You just haven@t let them out yet. Miranda considers the potential truth of this.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m the one who dropped my entire life and moved someplace I@ve never even visited before. I should get to figure out why the hell I did it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sits at the same table as the day before, a cup o in front of her. She@s been sleeping; she raises her head from where it was rest her arm and squints at the daylight. She sticks a finger in her coffee; it@s col gets our of her both.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda comes in and gets ready for bed. Linda Lue isn@t bed. We hear water running, then singing as she finishes her shower. The dog into Miranda@s bed.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Hey, Buster. Linda Lue comes out of the bathroom. She@s cheerful, a mo person. She seems a little hesitant about Miranda; she@s not sure if they@r fighting.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: His name ain@t Buster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Mr. Dog. Linda Lue says this as if it@В®s a perfectly normal name. pulls on boxer shorts.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How do you know his first name isn@t Buster? Linda Lue thinks. Miranda picks up the dog, puts him on a different part of the bed, and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well, he would have told me. We discuss practically everything.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Did you unpack my stuff?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I put your t-shirts in the second drawer, your underthings are in the top drawer, and pretty much everything else is in the closet, light to dark. Miranda looks at her disbelievingly; Linda Lue gets nervo

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Left to right. There was a lot of black. I guess you know that. I can@t wear black, it just washes me out. You ain@t mad, are you? She doesn@t seem the least bit mad.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Where are my tapes?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pointing) There, in the night table. You are mad.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I was thinking about what you said in the coffee shop. Linda Lue sits at the foot of the bed, her tone apologeti

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I@m trying to be more forthcoming.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Well, then let me ask you something. Linda Lue nods.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Don@t most motel rooms have one Bible? Linda Lue hops up and takes a Bible from one of the piles

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I made these myself. I work at the Praise The Lord print company.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You didn@t steal these.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Oh, lord no. These are all misprints. (picks one up, pages through it) This one has Chapter Four from Yogi Berra@s autobiography right in the middle of Revelations. Jesus comes back and says (CONT@D)

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: @lt ain@t over till it@s over.@ We couldn@t ship it that way. People might think Jesus had already come back, and he@s been Yogi Berra all along.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re making this up. Linda Lue nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did you think it was funny?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (laughs) Yes, I thought it was funny.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: These really are misprints, they@re just mostly upside down, though. But here@s a booklet that@s supposed to be on how to accept Jesus Christ as your lord and savior, and see, it@s all recipes for fun desserts you can make with Cool Whip. I didn@t make that up, swear to God.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m going to have to remember not to swear to anything in this room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, holding her guitar case, stands in front of the receptionist desk, talking to the RECEPTIONIST, an attractive young woman with a Tennessee

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: I@m sorry, he doesn@t see anyone without an appointment.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: O.K. Let@s make a appointment, then. Wednesday is good for me.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: You realize I go through this eleven times a day. I don@t let anyone slip through.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Ever? Not even like a really cute guy? The receptionist smiles and holds out her left hand, reve wedding ring.

dialogues.speaker: RECEPTIONIST
dialogues.text: That@s how I met my husband. I@m afraid I@m going to have to tell you what I tell  everyone: when you@re rich and famous, you can look back on this and thank God people like me no longer have any control over you life. Miranda realizes she@s not going to get anywhere, and lea office.

dialogues.speaker: CUT TO
dialogues.text: MONTAGE of shots of Miranda trying to get past the front other management companies on Music Row: She stands in front of another receptionist and pages thr receptionist@s desk calendar, pointing out an empty appointment time. The gir shakes her head no firmly. A receptionist pulls out a large cardboard box and shows Miranda; we see that it@s filled to overflowing with tapes. Miranda open the door at another company and finds a four band auditioning for an expressionless receptionist in the waiting area. Miran to leave, hoping she doesn@t look as ridiculous as that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The place is about half-full; the show hasn@t started yet Miranda, Linda Lue, Kyle, and James share a table near th

dialogues.speaker: MIRDANDA
dialogues.text: So he told me to come back after they closed and @try out@, in quotes and italics, because he@s be alone and his wife is like in Tulsa and I was like, @yYeah! Absolutely! I@11 be back. Is there any possibility you could gain some more weight by tonight, because I would fine that really sexy.В®

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You didn@t say that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did, actually. She looks around for their waitress.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Don@t we have a waitress?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: (to James) Now, don@t you be nervous. You@re going to be just fine. You get a case of the nerves, you arteries can explode. You could look healthy as a horse, except you@d be dead. I@ve seen it myself.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don@t get nervous. Thanks for trying to calm me down, though.

dialogues.speaker: MIRDANDA
dialogues.text: I@m going to the bar. Anyone want anything?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Beer.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Nothing till after I go on. Miranda looks at Linda Lue

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m not ordering a Shirley Temple.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Nothing for me, thanks. Miranda makes her way over to the bar. Nick, the audition dedicated his song to Lucy, sits on a barstool. Miranda orders from the bart

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Two beers and a Shirley Temple. The bartender raises his eyebrows. Miranda nods to confir order, then notices Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I know you, from the audition.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nick Reynolds

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Miranda Presley.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: That@s right. Miranda Presley. Wrote @DesperadoВ® when you were eight years old. Miranda smiles; she doesn@t seem embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m famous already, and I can@t even find a job.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Lucy just lost a waitress. Maybe she@1l give you a job.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. I@m hot a waitress, I@m a singer.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I@m not sure I see the difference. (calls to the back room) Lucy, come on out here. Lucy comes out of the back room, a look of annoyance on h She recognizes Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Well, if it isn@t Miss Presley. What can I do for you, honey?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: She@s interested in the waitress position. I told her you@d probably want to hire her. Both women look at Nick like they wish he@d butt out. The bartender pages through a booklet, looking for a Shirley Temple recipe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I don@t want to be a waitress.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Then why am I out here? Miranda looks at Nick accusingly.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don@t know, but you sure do look nice tonight, Lucy. You want to go out later?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Nick, I@ve got a million things to do. Darcy called me at four in the afternoon to tell me she was quitting.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (mock surprise) Quitting? Why?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Oh, she@s going on tour with Rodney Crowell or some fool thing.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: What@s she going to do? Drive the bus? Nick knows very well what Darcy@s going to do.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: (to Miranda) Darcy@s a singer. She met Rodney Crowell right in the very establishment, slipped him a tape, which is against the rules, and now she@s singing back-up on his tour. Nick@s a sucker for a happy ending, but they@re few and far between, if you ask me. Lucy heads for the back room.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Lucy. She turns around.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I just wanted to apologize. For singing @DesperadoВ® at the audition. I knew I was supposed to sing something I wrote.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No apology necessary. Just don@t pull that again. You@re welcome to try out anytime with something of your own. (sighs) And you can have the waitress job, if you decide you@re interested by tomorrow afternoon. But no passing tapes to the customers. Lucy goes into the back room. The bartender has finally f the Shirley Temple, and Miranda picks up her drinks.

dialogues.speaker: MIRDANDA
dialogues.text: (to Nick) You think I should take this job, don@t you?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: If you think opportunity keeps dropping by until you like what he@s wearing, you might as well pass this up.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Ever since I crossed the border into Tennessee, It@s been an exercise in logic to get a yes or no answer.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Personally, I think you should take the job. You got the voice to make it someday. Miranda is surprised at the flattery, but still concerned

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How long did Darcy work here?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You don@t want to know. Miranda goes back to her table. James is going onstage. T audience applauds. He@s confident, poised. Two or three musicians assemble him to back him up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hi. I@m James Wynn. I@m from Austin, where we like our music with a few rough edges. I hope that@s all right with y@all. If you like this one, maybe you can tell Lucy, let her know Nashville@s ready for something new for a change. Miranda looks confused. She turns to Kyle.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I heard he wanted Lucky to let him play without an audition. He had all these reviews from when he played in Austin. I also heard that he shot a record executive in Austin, but I don@t think that part@s true. James signals the band and they kick in with an energetic rockabilly-flavored song. He@s definitely showing he has the talent to back up his

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James leans against his truck, drinking a beer, talking t guys who played behind him. Miranda, Linda Lue and Kyle come out of the bar. Jam says goodnight to the musicians and calls out to Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Miranda. Come here. She walks over to him, leaving Linda Lue and Kyle waiting

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You were good.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Did you ever have a nickname?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Is that why you called me over?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No. That was an icebreaker. He reaches out and takes her hand, surprising her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. Did you? He shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You want to go out? Right now?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Only if you do. Kyle@s talking to Linda Lue. He looks over and sees James Miranda@s hand and stops mid-sentence. Linda Lue turns to look and sees get into James@s truck.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I guess she found a ride. (calls out) James. How many beers have you had? James hold up his beer bottle and tosses it in the trash.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: One half. O.K.? I promise not to run down any of your relatives.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Have a nice time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A large, empty bowling alley parking lot. James@s truck t in circles, tires squealing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Inside the truck, we see that Miranda is driving. She gri gears and wrestles with the steering wheel. Speed seems to be her only objective.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I can@t believe you@ve never driven  before.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m doing that well?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No. I put that wrong. I believe you when you say you@ve never driven before. A blind man could see you@ve never driven before. Miranda gives him a look and drives over a cement parking James gets an idea.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I know. Step on the middle pedal. She hits the brake. The car stalls.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: My fault. I forgot to remind you about the clutch. He opens the glove box and pulls out a bandana. He holds front of Miranda, trying to put it on her like a blindfold. She looks at hi he@s nuts.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe this works with other girls

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Trust me. She lets him blindfold her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda drives with the blindfold on. She@s doing much be driving in slow circles. James periodically tells her when to turn, putting his ha steering wheel to help her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Not too many people know this, but  Nashville has a giant magnet - it@s right under this very parking lot - that pulls things in. People, pick-up trucks, old Roy Orbison eight-tracks. It pulled you here. Turn left. She turns to look at him, but can@t because of the bandan

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Why didn@t it pull anybody else I know?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It doesn@t attract everyone. Just hicks and hillbillies and a few rednecks. Songwriters. People who own cowboy hats,

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: guys with mustaches. If you have a pick-up, sometimes it@ll get pulled with you in it. Some people try to ignore it; they get used to the pull and just never come. My theory about you is that you@ve got this stray piece of hillbilly lodged in you, probably in one of your shoulders. You were smart not to fight it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You know how you can have a job and an apartment and friends and you think, this is my life. If I leave this, I have no life.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Mmm. Turn right. She makes the turn easily, not thinking about the driving

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Well, I woke up a few weeks ago and it was really hot out and sunny and there were kids everywhere. It was the first day of summer vacation, and it was just like every other day to me. I wanted to be out, like they were. I just wanted out. And I thought, nothing@s holding me here, I can do whatever the hell I want. And if I don@t do it now, I@ll keep going  forever doing what I think I have to do when actually the only thing that@В®s definite about my life is that I@m in it. I@m the fucking lead. I left the next day.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That happened to me when I was seventeen.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: And I@ve always wanted to see Graceland.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: How fast are you going?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: About twenty?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Fourteen. Shift down and make a sharp right when I say now. ... . Now. Miranda follows his instructions and pulls smoothly onto highway

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Speed up. She does, shifting into third.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Faster. Get into fourth.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Fourth? I can@t go that fast in a parking lot.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Promise me you won@t panic. He pulls off her blindfold and she sees that she@s drivin highway. She smiles, proud of herself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda and James lie on their stomachs in the back of hi truck, looking off  into the distance.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@ve got a strange idea of a good time.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It@s better this way. We see that they are watching a drive-in movie, except th at the drive-in; they@re parked overlooking the drive-in. They have a good the screen, but no speaker. It@s a clear summer night, just barely dark out. movie is @Love Story.В®

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You can make up your own story. James sits up and reaches for his guitar. He starts to st guitar, nods in the direction of the screen and sings the first line of a son it up as he goes along. He plays, waiting for Miranda to do the second line. She He keeps making up lines, making the song about the characters in the movie. Suddenly, Miranda comes up with a line of her own; it@s just as good as one of James makes up the chorus and they sing together. Miranda rolls over on her back and stares at the sky, her flopped out the back of the truck.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I didn@t know there were this many stars.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Giant magnet. What@s your favorite song? Miranda answers without hesitation.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: @Hooked on a FeelingВ®.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Liar.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I think you can feel secure in your position as the only person on the planet whose favorite song is @Hooked on a FeelingВ®.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What@s yours?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. Me too. James laughs.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What can you do that no one else can do?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: There@s always something.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I can do a country version of any Bon Jovi song. Any Bon Jovi single. Except @Lay Your Hands on Me.@ What about you?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I speak Spanish.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So do a billion other people.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Last month, I punched a record producer in the face.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I heard you shot him. Only he was a label executive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, you should never believe rumors.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So what happened?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I met this producer in Austin, who wanted to do some demos with me, try and get me a record deal. then as soon as we got into the studio, he started changing my songs, fucking with them so they@d sound more like everyone else. We had a fundamental difference of opinion. And he was a dick.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So you punched him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I believe in doing what you feel like doing at any moment in time.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What@s it like, when you sing something you wrote?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Don@t you write songs?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. I think I might try it, though. This singing thing isn@t really working out.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: The first time I played one of my songs and people connected with it, it was like sex. Well, not exactly. Like the first time you kiss someone and your heart kind of flips, except it doesn@t make you feel weak, it makes you feel strong. If you think it@В®s something you want to do, you should try it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I think it@s something I want to do. They look straight at each other, lean towards each other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda walks down the sidewalk toward Lucy@s. she passes laundromat. Inside, a man sits on a washing machine playing his guitar and sing his clothes spin in the dryer. Miranda stops and listens to him a moment; he@ bad. She continues down the sidewalk and goes inside Lucy@s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two singers perform on stage. We see Miranda moving throu crowd, working as a waitress. She@s not having an easy time; she sets a bee front of a customer and he indicates that it@s not what he ordered and makes her tak She carries the bottle back to the bar, where Nick sits at his usual post.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Did I thank you for bringing glamour and excitement into my dreary life?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Did you mess up another one? She slides the bottle over to the bartender.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (to bartender) Michelob. (to Nick) Beer all tastes the same to me. Did you ask her out yet today?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (nods) She declined. Thanks for inquiring.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe it@s time to fish or cut bait.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You know that Lyle Lovett song? Waltzing Fool?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing a capella) The waltzing fool, he just might be crazy, cause the waltzing fool keeps the moon in his car.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What about it?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Nothing. Silence. Miranda stares at Nick, waiting.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Just might no be so crazy, that@s all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s the middle of the night, pitch dark. A few of the ho have their lights on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda is in a recording studio, singing the last few li ballad (e.g. @lIs there life out there?@) over a guitar track recorded earlier. K in the booth alone, operating the board.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I could do it better. Let me do it one more time.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: No. I@m keeping that one.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: We have fifteen minutes. I can do it better.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Miranda. That one was perfect. Wynonna Judd would use that one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle and Miranda come out of the building where they were recording. The walk down the sidewalk, Kyle carrying Miranda@s guitar. Miranda loo not stepping on cracks.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So what are you going to do with the demo?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: They@1ll put it on a list of available songs, and if someone comes in and wants something like this, they might listen to it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: That@s it? That@s how you@re getting it heard? That@s a great song, better than most of the stuff on the radio.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: They all sound that way at first, when you@re the only one who@s ever hear it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m telling you, someone wants this song. Wynonna Judd want this song, she just doesn@t know it yet.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: If that@s true, she@ll find out soon enough.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: O.K. It@s your song. I@m going to say two more words.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Two words.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No wonder. She keeps walking. Kyle stops.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: No wonder what? She doesn@t answer. He thinks.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: No wonder I can@t get anything recorded? No wonder I@1l1l be just another guy who never did what he said he was going to? No wonder I work in a record store? Because I didn@t push my songs on every singer I met? (seems to realize something) Well, I did that, for awhile, but those songs weren@t that good Miranda stops walking. She turns and looks at Kyle.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: For your information, I stopped putting all my energy into every new song because I didn@t want to be so damned disappointed all the time. Miranda looks guilty. She begins an apology.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Kyle. Kyle sits down on the curb. Miranda sits next to him.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (realizing) You@re right. No wonder. How can I expect anyone else to get excited about my songs if I don@t? I shouldn@t just sit back and wait for someone to find my songs; I should do something to get my songs heard He tries to think of an idea.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What do you think I should do? Miranda takes the demo tape out of her pocket.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I think you should - we should - take this song to Wynonna and get her to listen to  it. She stands up. Kyle remains sitting. She tilts her head - gesture for him to come on, then stars walking away.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What, right now? He gets up and follows her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There@s a car parked in the circular driveway. Kyle and M approach the car, trying to be inconspicuous.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is the right house? She parks right out front? Anyone could break into her car.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I guess we@re the only ones who thought of it. It@s her house. I came to a party here once.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So you@re in her social circle, but we have to lurk around at dawn to give her a tape.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I was parking cars, and this wasn@t my idea.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Give me the thing. Kyle hands her a slim jim.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: The thing? I thought you had done this before.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What do you think I am, a criminal? I@ve see it done. My sixth-grade boyfriend is  doing eighteen months for this. Kyle puts his hand on her wrist to stop her.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: O.K. Time to go.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: That was a joke. He got probation. She carefully inserts the slim jim between the car window door. She moves it around expertly, and after a few seconds the door lock cl Kyle jumps.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Give me the tape. Kyle hands her the tape. She opens the car door. As soon raises the handle, the car alarm goes off.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Shit. Let@s go.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Wait. Let me put the tape in. She sits in the driver@s seat and pop@s the tape in the c

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Take that out. It has my name on it. Miranda rolls her eyes at him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How else is she going to know whose song it is?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: But she@ll know I broke into her car.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Of course she will. That@s the one drawback to the plan.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I can@t believe I didn@t think of that. The alarm continues to blare. A light comes on inside th Kyle looks up and sees it. Miranda follows his gaze and sees it too.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Don@t people ignore these things anymore? She gets out of the car. Kyle gets in a pushes buttons on tape player.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Where@s the eject? Miranda hears something; she looks down the driveway and police car pulling up.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: And when did the cops start responding so quickly?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle sits in one of a row of chairs against the wall. He angry. Miranda leans over the receiving desk, pleasing with an unsympathetic cop.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I told you, we weren@t trying to steal anything. We were giving her a tape.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (weary) Don@t arrest her. It was my idea.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It was my idea. The cop looks from one to the other; he doesn@t care whos it was.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: At least you admit that.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Why are you mad at me? You agreed to it.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You didn@t mention the one drawback.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Any idiot would have figured out the one the one drawback. WYNONNA JUDD walks into the police station, a police offi her side. Everyone turns to look at her. The unsympathetic desk cop seems particularly impressed to see her.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: and my daughter just loves your last album. I like that one you did with your mama : (singing) @Girls night out, honey there ain@t no doubt... @ He notices everyone looking at him and stops singing. He at Kyle and Miranda.

dialogues.speaker: POLICMAN
dialogues.text: These here are your perpetrators. Kyle extends his right hand.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Hi. Kyle Davidson. It@s a pleasure to meet you. Wynonna shakes his hand. Miranda looks at him like he@s n

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: This is Miranda Presley.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Hi.

dialogues.speaker: WYNONNA
dialogues.text: Kind of polite for hardened criminals. Which one of you jimmied open my car door? Miranda raises her hand. The cop behind the counter stops at Wynonna and rushes over to a desk. He starts rummaging through drawer

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We weren@t trying to steal it

dialogues.speaker: WYNONNA
dialogues.text: (to Miranda) Thanks for not scratching it. You@re the one singing on the tape?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (nods) It@s his song. You listened to the tape?

dialogues.speaker: WYNONNA
dialogues.text: (to Kyle) I guess this song is available? Or are you waiting to hear from everyone else whose car you broke into?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Yours was the only car we broke into

dialogues.speaker: WYNONNA
dialogues.text: Well, I@m flattered. I just wish I wasn@t flattered this early in the morning. Is your phone number on the tape? Kyle nods, embarrassed at his stupidity.

dialogues.speaker: WYNONNA
dialogues.text: I@1ll have my manager give you a call about putting it on hold. Kyle@s mouth drops open. Miranda smiles. Wynonna turns to the police station.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Miss Judd? Do you want to press charges?

dialogues.speaker: WYNONNA
dialogues.text: All I want is to get some sleep.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (to Miranda) Don@t think this means I forgive you. The copy going through his desk finds what he@s looking f holds up a tape,  triumphantly, looks up and sees Wynonna leaving.

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Miss Judd? She turns to look at him. He hurries to catch up with her

dialogues.speaker: POLICEMAN
dialogues.text: Since you@re looking for new material. He offers her the tape. She takes it from him patiently, to listen to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sits in her usual booth, but this time she@s awak has her guitar next to her and her notebook open in front of her, trying to writ It doesn@t seem to be going too well, most of what she@s written has been cross She reads what she still ahs and crosses that out too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda and James are in the truck. Miranda drives.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m having trouble even getting started. Maybe I can@t do it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You learned how to drive two weeks ago and you@re already the best driver I know.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Writing songs is different.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Maybe you need to try it with your eyes closed. She looks at him and shakes her head, swerving expertly a car at the same time.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Tried it. Didn@t work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When@s your night off?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Wednesday.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Wednesday. I@ll show you a few tricks. But you have to promise not to get better than me. Miranda pulls into the parking lot for Lucy@s.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The caf@ hasn@t opened yet. Miranda opens the door, showi for work. James is with her; they kiss goodbye passionately. Lucy looks at t disapproving. Miranda comes in and ties an apron around her waist. Lucy puts gl away behind the bar. Nick is onstage, doing a sound check for his performance

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (into microphone) Check, check. Lucy . . . Lucy? Is this working right? Lucy finally looks up.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: The microphone is fine, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: You@re pretty fine, yourself, Lucy. Lucy goes back to work. Miranda smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Can I ask you something?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: If you think there@s something you don@t already know.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How long has he been after you like this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A little over a year. In the background, Nick starts to strum his guitar.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: And you@ve never even gone out with him?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) She won@t even give me a chance. Lucy sighs; she doesn@t think this is nearly as interesti Miranda does.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I expect you@ll keep asking me about this until you hear the whole sorry story. Miranda looks at her expectantly.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) She calls me sorry, and that@s just what I am

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I met Nick about. . . eight years ago. My husband and him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Your husband? Nick starts a new song, with a different melody.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) That no good man wasn@t no good for you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: My husband played guitar in Nick@s band. Nick started acting pretty much the way he acts now, only then I was young and didn@t have much sense. NICK (singing) I wouldn@t give you a dollar, for all the sense in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I eventually left my husband and took up with him She jerks her head in Nick@s direction.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What happened?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) It was the right love, at the wrong time.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Nick got a record deal. He cut an album and went on tour. His first night on the road, he called me up and started talking about. . . what was it, Nick? Space?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) Now it seems all the space in the world, is between me and you.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Well, his album didn@t exactly set any sales records, and his record label dropped him. Before I knew it he was hanging around here, thinking I was fool enough to take him back.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) You don@t want to fool, with this fool in love with you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe he@s learned his lesson.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) But I@ve learned my lesson, you taught me the hard way to fall.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: He hasn@t said anything so far to make me think he@s learned one damn thing. I2@m  going to open up. She walks over to unlock the front door.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: (singing) Open up your heart to me, darling, this time I won@t let you down.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Get off my stage, Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda@s just getting off work. She comes outside and lo around for something. She sees Kyle, leaning against his truck. Miranda stays w is. Kyle walks over to her.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I told Linda Lue I1@d pick you up. I thought we might celebrate. She looks at him doubtfully.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Any idiot would have figured out the one drawback. Miranda smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda and Kyle walk along the strip on night clubs and shops. It@s a warm night, and they pass musicians playing on the sidewalk fo They pass an open bottle of champagne back and forth, drinking straight out bottle.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: It@s lucky for both of us that my song was so good, or we@d be in jail right now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It@s lucky for you that I sang on that demo.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Hey, I can sing pretty good, I@ll have you know.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@1l have to show me that sometime. Kyle walks over to one of the street musicians and borrow guitar. He leans against a wall and begins to play; Miranda and the musician watch starts to sing; it@s the love song he did at the auditions, the one Miranda sa in the parking lot. Kyle does it a lot better than when he auditioned; he loo Miranda and sings the words to her. He finishes, showing no signs of embarrassm hands the guitar back to the musician.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Thanks, buddy. He and Miranda walk away.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Not bad. She hands him the champagne bottle.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Not bad? Not bad!

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re Johnny Cash. You@re Vince Gill. You@re George Strait. He puts his arm around her, and she leans her head agains shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You know what@s funny? Miranda doesn@t answer.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: The first time I saw you, I didn@В®t even realize how beautiful you were. She seems affected by this, but only for a moment. She p from him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Just once, I@d like a sober man to call me beautiful.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: It@s not just that, it@s you. I didn@t even care that I got arrested, really, because I was with you. You know how I got better at that song? Miranda@s look says she doesn@t want to know.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I thought about you. About everything I wanted to tell you about how I feel. And I was sober at the time, I promise. Kyle moves toward her. She moves away, starts walking aga trying to lighten the mood.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So you realize there@s a song for everything that happens in life? Sometimes there are dozens for one moment in time, like now. Yours could be that REO Speedwagon song about wanting to be more than friends, and mine could be @Baby don@t get hooked on me.В®

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I@ve always hated that song.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I got you arrested and I@ll always remind you of a song that you hate. That should be two strike against me.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Don@t count on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Miranda come up to a gate, carrying their guita walks up to the window and watches a plan taxi up to the gate. Miranda p in a chair.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I think you@re mistaken about how easy it is to amuse me. It@s harder than this. James walks over and sits next to her. He takes out his g

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We@re not here to amuse you, we@re her to get you some inspiration. Look at him. He points at an old man carrying a small bunch of daisies stands looking expectantly at the gate. Miranda looks at him, unimpresse

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Waiting for his wife. The woman he married when she was barely seventeen. The woman he loves just as much today as the day he met her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You could write a song from that?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No. Not me. I don@t write about everlasting love.
