dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Say he@s waiting for Gregor, his thirty- year-old Dutch lover. They met in Venice last Valentine@s day, and have been apart since then.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: How come?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Howard over there had to have his wife killed, and her collection of exotic parrots converted into hatbands.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Should be a touching reunion. Not a country song, though. What about him? James points at a man, about 35, who looks anxiously out window at the plane.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: He married his high school sweetheart, they have a lovely home and a wonderful marriage, or so everyone think. She@s returning from a Mary Kay convention.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Or so she says. That has possibilities. He plays a few chords and sings a line about the American gone wrong. The door opens and passengers start coming into the gate old man searches each face, almost as if he@s frightened. Suddenly his fac up. A short blue-eyed woman comes to him, her smile just like his. He holds her tightly, his fist clenching the daisies behind her back. Nearby, a young couple kisse passionately. James looks at Miranda; he told her so. Miranda stars at couple, who break apart as if slightly embarrassed. The man picks up the wo bags. He@В®s forgotten to give her the flowers. The young couple continues to ki The man who was looking out the window is standing on the the crowd of passengers, searching for someone.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Watch him. Finally the man sees who he he@s looking for; a five-year gets off the plane, holding the stewardess@ hand. The little girl sees him an free of the stewardess. She yells @Daddy!@ and runs to her father, who kneels dow catches her, lifting her in his arms. She wraps her little legs around him and hug neck tightly; you couldn@t find an inch of space between them. The father closes his eyes for a moment, smiling. James looks at Miranda, who stares at the father and dau She looks like she@s about to cry. She turns away, embarrassed.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Let@s go. She picks up her guitar and walks quickly away from the c gate, down the corridor. James hurries to catch up with her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What@s the matter?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Nothing.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: O.K. You don@t have to tell me. Miranda steps at an empty waiting area and takes a seat. sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I hate that. Someone goes away for two weeks and it@s like the end of the fucking world.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What@s wrong with missing someone?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: If you know they@re coming back, you have no right to miss them. It@s not like they@re dead. They sit there a little while, James sensing that Miranda upset about something.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I remember when my grandfather died. I kept waiting for him to come to Sunday dinner.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How old were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty. Miranda looks at him, a little surprised. She hesitates, opens her locket and shows him inside.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: That@s my dad. One side has a black and white photo of her father, a han with a wide grin. The other side has a black and white photo of Elvis pouti James tries a little joke.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: He looks just like Elvis.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: That is Elvis. He gave me this when I was ten. My decitennial accolade, he called it. He raised me since I was five. Just me and him. She looks at the pictures, then snaps the locket shut dro around her neck.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Presley@s my middle name. He had this kind of Elvis thing. Nothing weird.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: When did he die?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Three months ago.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: That@s not very long. It@s only natural that you miss him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t miss him. He told me not to. Miranda@s quiet. James just sits with her, comfortable wi silence.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You want to go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James sits in a deck chair. Miranda sits on the diving bo dangling her toes in the water. It@s a hot summer night; she wears a t-shirt and s She has her guitar, and is singing @Bad Medicine@, which she@s transformed from p to country. She does the first verse, then:

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: When I get married, I@m going to have them play @Bad MedicineВ® as I walk down the aisle. The Bon Jovi version. Miranda climbs off the diving board and sets her guitar i She goes over to the pool stops and starts to climb in fully dressed. James starts to play something; it@s the song he started earlier, in the airport, about living the American dream, but only on the surface. few really good lines. By the he@s done, Miranda has gotten all the way i pool, except for her head. She@s been watching him intently the whole time he@ singing. James puts down his guitar and sits at the edge of the pool.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Why do you always stay up all night?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Linda Lue snores.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Are you afraid of the dark?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: If I was afraid on the dark, I wouldn@t spend so much time in the dark, would I? James pulls off his shirt and starts to climb into the p Miranda ducks underwater and comes back up.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Nightmares?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Not since I was eight.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What@d you do then, when you a nightmare?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I would wake up my dad, he@d come get me, and he@d let me stay up all night. We@d light candles and make cookies and play poker. We used to crank call foreign countries. I learned the twist at four in the morning. Then when it got light out, I@d go to bed and miss half a day of school. My dad once wrote a not for me; @Miranda was unavoidably late to school today due to a slight pterodactyl crisis at home. The problem has been remedied and it is unlikely that this will happen again.@ They move around the shallow end of the pool, not approac other.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: So you@ve been sleeping during the day since he died?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: At first, I couldn@t sleep at all, then the only time I could even remember what he looked like was in the middle of the night. I sometimes think about what I@l1l say when I see him again, and if I@ll recognize him, then I realize I won@t see him again at all. James moves over to Miranda and stands in front of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I@ve been thinking about something. (He takes her hands.)

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I wonder if I@l1l1l know you in a year.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don@t know. James moves toward her, trying to seduce her. she@s going to respond.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: If we go out, and we break up, I probably won@t. I@ll be just another girl you used to go out with. And someday there@1ll be so many you won@t know which one I was. James backs away from her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You want me to say we@ll be together ina year? Because I can@t say that.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. That@s not what I want. It@s not clear if A look of realization crosses his face. He lets go of her

dialogues.text: You don@t want to do this.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t think it@s a good idea. James gets out of the pool; he@s angry and he@s leaving. up his shirt and starts to walk away, then stops and turns to Miranda.

dialogues.text: I@m going to have to ask you to tell me why.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I told you.

dialogues.text: I need the real reason. Then we@ll be friends or whatever it is you want. Miranda sits on the top step on the pool. She looks away an tells him the truth.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@ve been trying to write a song. Just one song, to prove I can do it. Not even a good song. And you, you see two strangers at an airport and you turn it into something so. . . incredible. Your song was incredible.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What, you@re jealous? I might not even finish that song. I have a song I started three years ago that@s not done yet.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m not jealous. I@m overwhelmed. I just can@t give you that, see?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don@t care.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I do. She stares at him. He sees she@s set on this and gives up away. She sits in the pool, holding her knees to her chest, watching him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night. The performances are over, and only a f songwriters hang around, making arrangements to get together and write. Miranda pu last chair up. She goes over to Lucy, who@s counting receipts at one of the

dialogues.text: You can leave if you want, honey. Miranda sits with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lucy, do you think anyone can be a songwriter

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I@ve seen some people who tried about as hard as a person can try and just never get it, you know? I don@t think you can learn it. I can@t do it. Miranda looks discouraged.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I didn@t mean to bring you down.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I always thought I wanted to be a singer, then I came hear and realized I like to sing, but it doesn@t seem like enough. But songwriting@s so different; I just don@t know if it@s worth it to try. It comes so easily to some people, like James.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You know what@s in this case? She points to the glass case on the wall behind her, whic contains tacked-up papers with handwriting on them: pages torn from notebooks, cock napkins, an air- sickness bag. Miranda looks and shakes her head no. Lucy up and examines the writing.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: These are all songs, by my songwriters. Theyre not all hits, but they@re special songs. @Like a miracle, some golden words roll off of someone@s tongue.@ Some of the took ten minutes, some if them took years. Every one of these songwriters would tell you it@s worth it. You write a song like one of these, and you can@t ever give up again. You know what it feels like to be special, and there@s nothing  and no one that can give you that same kind of special. Lucy sits back down to get back to work.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That@s why I worry about you, being with James.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: James and I decided we@d just be friends. Lucy nods.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: It doesn@t matter how wonderful he is if he@s only going to break you heart.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, that@s what I decided. I@l1l see you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Goodnight, honey. Miranda leaves. Nick@s standing nearby. He watches her go

dialogues.text: Lucy announces the results of the audition. She calls out name; he passed this time. Linda Lue lets out a whoop and hugs him. Miranda sm too. Lucy get to the end of the list. Linda Lue wasn@t on it; was Miranda. Linda Lue looks disappointed. Miranda takes the news well.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You should have passed. Miranda shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it wasn@t ready. I can do it better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that day, after the auditions are over, Miranda has up for work and is tying on an apron around her waist. Lucy comes in. Mirand smiles at her, showing her she@s not angry about the audition.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Hey, I thought you did real good today.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re supposed to pass the ones you like.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You know why I bought my own place?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So you could play God.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: That@s exactly right, honey. I think you got a real good start, but I wouldn@t be doing you any favors if I let you play this soon.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, I brought you something. Miranda holds out a cassette . Lucy takes it.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What@s this?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: If I tell you to just trust me and listen to this, will you? Lucy shakes her head.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It@s Nick, a song of his. I think you should hear it.  (smiles) It@s all about you. And it won@t get any laughs. Lucy sets the tape on the counter. Miranda won@t take it she walks away. Lucy looks at the tape.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda and Linda Lue are taking the dog for a walk. Mira holds a flyer advertising the Miss Nashville pageant.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: And there@s prizes, and scholarships, and the winner goes to the Miss Tennessee pageant. They come up to a playground.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I hope you won@t be insulted if I tell you I already think of you as Miss Nashville. What about your illustrious songwriting career? They come up to the slide. Miranda picks up the dog and c him to the top of the slide.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: You have no way of knowing this, since you are asleep during most of my waking hours, but I have been having serious doubts about my future as a songwriter, which has been my one goal since I was eleven years old and saw @Coal Miner@s DaughterВ® for the first time. Miranda places the dog at the top of the slide and hold h facing towards the drop. The dog starts to wiggle eagerly and she lets him g slides to the bottom, where Linda Lue catches him and carries him around to do

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: But lately I@ve been thinking about something my late grandmother Tilly use  to say. She would say, @lLook at your breakfast. You@ve got your bacon, and your eggs. Now, the hen was involved in your breakfast, but that hog was committed. @ Linda Lue releases the dog down the slide to Miranda. The continue to take turns putting the dog down the slide.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Lately I@ve been feeling more like that hen. If I thought I could really do it, that might be another story.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: The pageant@s next week? Do you have time to get ready? Don@t people train for months for these things?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Miranda, I believe it is within my ability to learn to walk in high heel, discuss (CONT@D)

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: the role of the woman in today@s society, and tease my hair in one week.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: If you could have one wish for today@s children, what would it be?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: World peace. No, clean air.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You wouldn@t want them to be sick, or go hungry, would you?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: What do I care? TI hate kids.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re beautiful and queen-like, Lou. You@re a beauty queen. You@ve got this locked up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is in the recording studio with a band of session m

dialogues.speaker: DOUG ROBERTS,
dialogues.text: the manager who gave James his card at the Roadhouse, sit booth with the engineer. The musicians are all in their thirties and for most of them look like somebody@s father. They@re doing one of the songs we@ve h James do before, but this version seems to lack energy. James is clearly dissa with the way things are going, but is trying to be patient. He stops singing in t middle of the song and cuts the band.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We need to bring up the snares.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: (over microphone) They sound fine in here.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: This tempo@s all wrong.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Don@t worry. It sounds great.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I@m not deaf. I can tell how it sounds. From the way he says this, we know he hates the way it so

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: We@11l just get it down once this way, 0.k. James?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No. That@s not the way I wrote it. James looks determined. Doug leaves the booth and comes i studio to talk some sense into James. The musicians watch, uninterested. They this before.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: James, I know you feel strongly about your  song. You should, it@s your baby. But I@ve been doing this since you were a baby. I know what a hit sounds like. Doug@s matter is soothing, condescending.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I know what shit sounds like.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: It doesn@t sound like shit. It sounds like what every country radio station is looking for. I have to think in terms of radio play.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I record this the way I wrote it, or I don@t record it at all. The musicians start to take notice; the fight is finally up.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: I@m already taking a big risk with you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Don@t do me any favors. He starts to gather up his stuff.

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: Go ahead. Walk out. No one else will touch you. Everyone knows about you. James stands face to face with Doug.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What does everyone know about me?

dialogues.speaker: DOUG
dialogues.text: You@ve got a hell of an attitude for a pretty boy with a couple of good songs. This is just part of Doug@s act, the way he keeps singers but James@В® anger flashes. Before Doug can see it coming, James punches him eye. The musicians look at each other, entertained. James wal

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, wearing her t-shirt and boxer shorts with a glit of high heels, paces the floor with a Bible balanced on her head.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I pledge allegiance, to the flag, of the United States. Linda Lue calls to her from the bathroom.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: I think it@s highly unlikely I@11l be reciting the pledge of allegiance. Linda Lue sticks her head out the bathroom door, pulling out of her hair.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Much less with a Bible on my head. Miranda puts her arms straight out at her sides and the B off her head.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I would think this is exactly the kind of thing you@d be doing. I still think you should learn that tap dance to @Dixie.В® Come on out. Linda Lue throws open the bathroom door and strikes a pos doorway, one arm raised, head thrown back. She wears a low-cut sequined go heavy make-up and has her curled hair piled on top of her head. Miranda gas

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Oh, you look beautiful. Linda Lue drops the pose and looks down at herself.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: You think so? Is it enough?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yes. It@s enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s not too much?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. You look perfect. Except. . . let me try one thing. She reaches up and loosens a few strands of Linda Lue@s h they fall around her face. Miranda steps back and appraises her work.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Better. Wait. Miranda reaches to the dressing table and gets a Q-tip. S the Q-tip under Linda Lue@s eye, removing some of the eyeliner, then does the s the other eye.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: What did you do, follow some kind of eyeliner diagram in the beauty queen handbook?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I@ll be on stage, I want them to see my eyes.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: They will see your eyes. On the other girls, all they@ll see is eyeliner. They turn to face the mirror and look at themselves, stan by side. Linda Lue gets a little emotional.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: You@re my best friend, you know. Miranda@s emotional too, but embarrassed. She turns away the mirror.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah, well that@s cause you@re such a sap, Lou. Linda Lue smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s closing time. Lucy@s behind the bar, Nick is there a usual seat. He gets up to leave.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Goodnight, Lucy.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Goodnight.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: I don@t suppose you want to go out with me tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Tomorrow night? Nick nods. If he@s surprised, it doesn@t show.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: What time?

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Eight o@clock.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Eight o@clock. That@ll be fine.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Goodnight, then. As he turns to leave, we see a small smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A record store with a small outdoor stage behind it, wher @jamboreesВ® are held at night. There@s an all-night miniature golf course next do Miranda and Linda Lue@s motel is just across the parking lot. It@s a warm n and people are playing golf, sitting in the adjacent picnic area or on top of th in the parking lot, listening to the music. This is a traditional country music affair; band is also made up of older musicians, all men, and includes a banjo an fiddle.  Miranda and Linda Lue sit on top of a picnic table. to them

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Hey. I got your note. He holds up a note which reads @James, JAMBOREE! @ arrow.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I never miss a jamboree.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Hey, James. How@s your career coming?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I punched an influential member of the record industry in the face. They don@t react to the news.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: We know.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Again. Today.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Oh. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I@11 tell you on the way.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: On the way where?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It@s a surprise. James takes her hands to help her down off the table. says goodbye to Linda Lue.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: This had better be better than the jamboree.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: James walks up with an Miranda  It is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Miranda in James@ truck, driving.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So when do I find out the surprise?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: There are clues everywhere. We@re ina truck, on the highway.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re talking me somewhere. James points to a road sign.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Clue.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (reading) Memphis. What@s in Memphis? James moves his lip in an Elvis sneer. Miranda screams.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Graceland? Graceland! Way cool.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You do not know what it is to worship Elvis until you@ve seen his personal shit.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: They should put that on a plaque and hand it on the gate. (singing) @Graceland, Graceland, Memphis Tennessee. We@re going to Graceland. . .В®

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Miranda are at the check-out stand, buying chee suzy-q@s and Dr. Pepper.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Only six hours to kill.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We@1l drive by the gate. I thought you would want to see it at night. They walk out of the supermarket. James stops by the gumb machines. He puts a quarter in one of the machines and turns the dial. He loo the prize, puts it in his jacket pocket, and tries another quarter. This time he ta prize out of the plastic bubble. He goes to Miranda and takes the grocery store ba her. He sets the bag on the ground and kneels in front of Miranda. James takes her left hand and shows her the prize - it@s colored ring with a blue plastic star. Miranda looks around, embarrassed. The checkers, two midd women (one white, one black), are both watching with smiles on their

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: They think you@re proposing. James doesn@t reply. He tries to put the ring on her ring but it doesn@t fit. He puts it on her pinky.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Get up. James looks over at the checkers.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Say yes first.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yes to what?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Say yes, or I@ll look like a loser.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You are kind of a loser.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (loudly) Say yes. I can@t live without you. One of the checkers says, @how romantic.@ They ignore a c trying to buy a six- pack.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (loudly, angrily) Yes. I said yes. Is that what you want? Are you happy now? James acts overjoyed; he smiles gleefully and hugs Mirand

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Happy? I@m the happiest man on earth! He looks at her and smiles stupidly until she finally has the act and laugh. They grab the groceries and run out of the store, leaving the bewildered.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James@ truck is parked across the street. James and Miran the back, eating chee-tos, looking at the gate.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: His aunt still lives there.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I bet she used the TV room at night.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I would. James looks pensively at the house.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You know what this reminds me of? He looks at Miranda; she has no idea.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: When I was a kid, my dad used to take me out every weekend. Told my mom we were  having a boysВ® night out, going bowling or to the movies, or the rodeo, if there was one. Then we@d go to his girlfriend@s house; for a long time he was seeing my fifth-grade health teacher. Miranda studies him, looking for signs of sadness at the and finding none.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: And I@d sit in the car, we had a blue Pontiac, and he@d leave me the keys, and I@d listen to the radio. (laughs) One night, I taught myself how to drive in that car, waiting for my dad. The antenna had this bend in it. . (motions with his hand) and no matter what I did I couldn@t get one damn FM station in that car. So I@d sit there and listen to the country music station and stare at the house. I never could take my eyes off the house. He takes Miranda@s hand, his eyes still on Graceland.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Just like all those damn cheating songs. And all my life, people would tell me, @James, you@re just like your father.@ And I never said it but I thought, no I@m not. I never lie. I don@t pretend to be a great guy. The high point of my father@s life was a football game in high school. No way was I going to be just like him. But now I wonder if I can help I it. Miranda looks confused.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Sometimes I feel like I@m going to spend the rest of my life with everyone thinking I@m someone I@m not.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It@s hard to think about what you@re going to do for the rest of your life. You have  to pick one thing. What if it doesn@t work out? James nods.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You look stupid. You@re a failure. Miranda takes his chin in her hand and turns his face tow She kisses him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t think you could ever be a failure. She climbs out of the truck bed. She reaches inside the t turns on the radio, tuning it to a slow song (e.g. @Asking us to dance@) . Sh climbs back up into the back and stands next to James, holding her hand out to him. He gets up, his eye locked with hers, and takes her hand. They start to dance underneath the stars, holding each ot close. James pulls her closer, tight against him, until they aren@t dancing anym

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (softly) I@m scared.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So aml. The song plays on as they hold on to each other. Finally, pulls away until he isn@t touching Miranda anymore. He takes his hand and mov along her arm, from the shoulder down to her wrist, without touching her.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Do you feel that?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. The skies have become cloudy. There@s lightning in the di Elvis comes on the radio and it begins to sprinkle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s pouring now. James and Miranda con in, drenched. The two checkers are there. Their names are SELMA and MARY. Mary is black.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Look, Mary, if it ain@t the newlyweds.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: You two get married already?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: No. We couldn@t find an all-night wedding chapel. Miranda plays her role low-key, convincingly bitchy.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Well, maybe if you had any sense at all, you might have planned this a little better and we wouldn@t have gotten lost in the rain. (to the cashiers) He doesn@t have the sense he was born with.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: (to James) You sure you wanna marry this one? James smiles fondly at Miranda

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I know she@s a handful, but I1@d die if I lost her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: That@s cause you@d forget to breathe if I didn@t remind you.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Well, if you@re sure, maybe I can help you. Selma, you can cover me for five minutes?

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Sure can. You gonna wake Raymond? Mary gets her purse from under the counter and pulls on rain hat.

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: I@m going to wake that man and tell him there@s two young folks here and can@t wait till morning to get married. Mary hurries out of the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: She@1ll be right back, she just lives down the street.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Who@s Raymond?

dialogues.speaker: SELMA
dialogues.text: Raymond@s her husband. He@s a minister. This is so romantic. Miranda and James look at each other, amused, mildly pani

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Cold feet, honey?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I left. . . something blue in the truck. Come with me. They leave the supermarket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They sit inside the truck, parked outside the supermarket

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Let@s go.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We can@t just go. We have to at least tell them we changed our mind.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (laughs) We@1l have a big blow-out of a fight. I@1l pretend to shoot you in the leg.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I@ve got another idea. She looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Let@s get married. She seems to consider this, then come to her senses.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You don@t get married as a joke.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: It@s not a joke. We@re in love. What the hell, let@s get married.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re serious.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We are in love, aren@t we?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Then why haven@t you ever told me?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re the one who had to write it on my hand.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I love you.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I can@t say it.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@d be afraid to tell you how much. James seems happy with this answer. He notices something Miranda, outside the window. Mary is back with her husband. He@s black man with a lumbering gait. He wears a black raincoat and carr black bible. Their skinny teen-age son is with them.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Jesus.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Oh my god. Raymond comes up to the truck and puts his face against t passenger window. It@s a frightening sight. Miranda covers her mout James reached over and turns Miranda@s face towards his.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Marry me, Miranda

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: O.K. Yes. She looks back at Raymond.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t see an alternative.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The frozen foods section has been selected as the wedding Mary and Selma drape pastel toilet paper over the aisles. Raymond some crates to use as a podium, placing one behind for him to stand on. son leans against the freezer, flipping through a Playboy. James is in the toiletries section, putting gel in his ha Miranda comes up next to him and takes a toothbrush and toothpaste.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I have chee-tos stuck in my teeth.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You know, this is exactly how I pictured my wedding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, mine too. Except. . . oh, shit. She quickly walks away, then back to James. She takes off ring and puts it in his hand.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: The ring. See you at the altar. Aisle twelve. Miranda hurries away. She goes to the frozen food section. Raymond has discover son reading Playboy.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Benjamin, I have told you that pornography will guarantee you reservation in the depths of hell. He gives special enunciation to the word @pornography@. B unconcerned. He puts down the magazine, revealing the Met logo on his t-shirt. Raymond hands Miranda a piece of paper.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Here@s your marriage license. Can@t no one tell you for certain that@s not the genuine article.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Thank you. She takes Ben@s arm and pulls him aside.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Ben, I need a favor.

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: (wicked smile) You want a lesson from the master. Before your honeymoon. She gives him a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have a Bon Jovi tape?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: Bon Jovi@s for girls, man. I ain@t a girl. My sister likes Bon Jovi.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Does your sister have a Bon Jovi tape?

dialogues.speaker: BEN
dialogues.text: She@s got every Bon Jovi tape. Miranda smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s time for the ceremony. Raymond stands behind his pod towering over James. Selma and Mary stand off to the side, beaming

dialogues.speaker: MARY
dialogues.text: Ben, where are you? Get out here and be a witness.

dialogues.speaker: BEN, (0O.S.)
dialogues.text: Coming There@s a click, then music comes over the supermarket so system. It@s @Bad Medicine.@ Ben escorts Miranda up the aisle until sh standing next to James, the runs back and cuts the music. Raymond being the ceremony. He@s a fundamentalists preach apparently, even his wedding ceremony is delivered with t of fire and brimstone.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: (bellowing) Dearly beloved.

dialogues.speaker: TIME CUT TO
dialogues.text: Later in the ceremony. Sweat drips down Raymond@s face as towers over  Miranda and James.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Do you, James, take this woman to be your wife, to love and treasure like gold, forsaking all others, turning your back on earthly temptations, or you will surely know the fires of hell in the inferno of eternal damnation. Raymond glares down at James, pointing his finger. James think it was a question, but it seems safer to answer.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I do. James slips the ring on her finger. Raymond draws a deep and pulls back.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: And do you, Miranda, take James to be your husband. Miranda seizes the opportunity to cut this short.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I do.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: Then by the power vested in my by Almighty God, his son, our savior, the baby Jesus and the state of Tennessee, I hereby pronounce you man. He points at James.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: and wife. His finger swings over to Miranda. Raymond wipes the swea forehead.

dialogues.speaker: RAYMOND
dialogues.text: You may kiss the bride. James and Miranda kiss. Ben cranks up @Bad Medicine@В® an and  Selma throw Minute Rice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James and Miranda dance. Eric Clapton@s @Pretty Girl@В® p over the sound system. Mary dances with Raymond, and Ben reluctantly dan with Selma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s morning. James and Miranda are inside Graceland. The guide describes the room in a loud, rehearsed voice. Miranda le against James and gazes dreamily at Elvis@В® stuff.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I had this dream that we got married.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: We did, remember?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. Me and Elvis. I had my hair ina huge bee-hive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The theater where the beauty pageant is being held. Linda onstage, doing a scene from @Coal Miner@s Daughter@. Someone read other parts woodenly from off-stage. Linda Lue is an extremely emotio actress and several women in the audience wipe tears from their eyes of her performance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pageant@s nearly over. There are five girls on stage: Lue is one of them. Miranda and James slink into the darkened theater a two empty seats next to Kyle.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (whispering)  Where were you two?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: We picked up a hitchhiker that turned out to be the ghost of Elvis. Had to take him to Graceland. She@s a finalist?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: She was the best one. People were crying when she did her scene.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So she@s going to win?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I don@t know. I think that redhead is married to at least one of the judges. On stage, Linda Lue walks over to stand next to the host.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: And now, our last finalist, Louise Linden. Miranda mouths the name @Louise@, amused.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: You look lovely tonight, Louise.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well, that@s the idea, ain@t it? The host chuckles.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: Yes, it is. Now, Louise, here@s your question: Which do you consider more important, family or career?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: By family you mean the family I plan to have.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: Yes.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Well in that case, I would say neither.  My friends are more important to me than my career, whatever that may turn out to be, and my career is more important to me than a husband and a bunch of screaming kids. The host clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: Thank you. A very good answer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later. Linda Lue and the redhead are the only contestants on stage.

dialogues.speaker: HOST
dialogues.text: And this year@s Miss Nashville is... Tammy Sue Phelps! Tammy Sue squeals. Linda Lue hugs her, looking relieved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda Lue stands among a group of contestants, holding a of roses. Miranda come up to her and hugs her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Congratulations. Personally, I thought you should have won.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I can@t believe they gave me runner-up after I said that about screaming kids. Miranda laughs.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You threw it? Cool. How come?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Did you see my talent?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. James and I got married. We got here late.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Married?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Sort of. I@11 tell you all about it. Tell me how your scene went.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: I was really good. I found something I can do, Miranda. I can@t spend a year cutting ribbons at supermarket openings.

dialogues.speaker: MIRDANA
dialogues.text: Well, you@1l always be a beauty queen to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle is in his pick-up, playing with the radio as he driv switches from station to station to station, trying to keep an eye on t traffic.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (to himself) Love songs, nothing but love songs Whose idea was love, anyway? He pauses on a station where the dee-jay is introducing a his hand poised over the dial.

dialogues.speaker: DEE-JAY, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: : we@ve all been waiting for, here@s the new one from Wynonna. The song starts; it@В®s Wynonna Judd, singing Kyle@s song realizes what it is, lets out a whoop and turns up the radio. In his excitement, he also puts his foot on the gas and runs right into another truck. Ev the accident, he@s still grinning and listening to the radio. He opens but stays in his truck. The driver he hit gets out, more surprised by the than angry. He approaches Kyle, looking at him curiously. Kyle beams He points at the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That@s my song. The driver doesn@t say anything. He leans against Kyle@s he can hear the song, and listens appreciatively. Then he calls out t people who are gathering around because of the accident.

dialogues.speaker: DRIVER
dialogues.text: That@s his song. He@s got a song on the radio! The on-lookers move in closer sot hey can hear the radio.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle@s song continues over: James and Miranda in bed. Miranda@s wide awake, staring a ceiling. James is still asleep. He stretches, waking up. Miranda turns and closes her eyes, pretending to be aslee looks a little surprised to find Miranda in his bed; we see the m the wedding coming back to him. Now it@s his turn to stare at the cei He reaches over and takes Miranda@s hand; the situation is serious b least they@re in it together. She doesn@t look at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is alone in the bathroom. He opens the medicine cab has to search for his shaving cream. He looks down and sees two toothpaste resting on opposite sides of the sink. He closes the medi cabinet and starts at the sight of his own reflection, as if he@s looking at for the first time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda looks in the refrigerator, which is nearly empty lifts the lid ona pizza box, takes out a slice and takes a bite. She sits d the kitchen table and looks out at the quiet street. Her eyes move down to hands. She holds them in front of her and examines them, like someon hands. She touches the ring James gave her, which looks cheap in the morning light. She twists it off her finger and holds it in her fist, dr knees up to her chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James pulls his truck up outside one of the houses, the o Doug Roberts@ management company. He stays inside the truck, l at the building.

dialogues.speaker: INT JAMES
dialogues.text: Miranda sits at the table, her notebook open in front of blank page. She slides the ring back and forth on her pen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doug sits behind his desk. He has a black eye. James stan front of him, pleading his case.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The music ends. Miranda shows up for work. Lucy looks sur to see her.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You@re early. Miranda looks at her watch.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I am?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Forty-five minutes. You feeling all right? You look exhausted. Miranda sits down at the bar.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (matter-of-fact) We got married.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: You and James? Congratulations! Miranda looks at Lucy like she things she might be joking

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I thought you might disapprove.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Well, honey, I got me a whole new attitude on the subject of love. She holds out her left hand. There@s a diamond ring on he finger. Miranda smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: This can@t be from Nick. You can@t even tolerate Nick. You@re never going to forgive him for as long as you live.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I changed my mind.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I tried to tell you about that song.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I don@t know why he didn@t just come out and tell me how he really felt.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe the same reason you didn@t tell him.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: We@re having an engagement party Friday. We@d like you to sing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Original material only.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Oh. I don@t have anything good enough

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Well, you@ve got two days. You@11l come up with something.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: When did you turn into such an optimist?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I have to admit, I@m starting to believe in happy endings. Looks at you and James - I never did figure that boy to be the type to commit.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: It kind of happened when he wasn@t looking.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: I don@t think he does anything without looking first. If he said @I do@, then he does. Miranda smiles, reassured.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Later that night, Miranda brings some customers their dri heads back to the bar. On her way, she runs into James.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Hey. I know you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Can you take a break?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Not right now.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You want to know what I did today?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What did you do today?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I went to see Doug. I told him he@d be all kinds of sorry if he let me get away. That kind of line works like you wouldn@t believe. Miranda smiles.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I might.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I leave for Austin day after tomorrow. I start recording next week. The smile leaves Miranda@s face.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Austin? You@re aware you@re already in the country music recording capital of the world.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I get to use my musicians this time. This is everything I wanted. I thought you@d be happy for me.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How long will you be gone?

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: I don@t know. A month or two.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: You@re just taking off? Day after tomorrow. And you aren@t going to ask me if I want to come. James is surprised that she@s upset. He looks around to s anyone is looking at them. No one is.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What are you going to do, quit your job so you can hang around and watch me record  all day? I thought you@d want to stay here.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (loudly) The fact that we@re married doesn@t mean that you get to decide what I want. Now a few people turn to look.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: What does it mean? She@s getting progressively louder, and so is James. Lucy notices that they@re fighting.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: 1@m not even sure we are married, so if you want out, just let me know. I can tear up the certificate.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Don@t pull this on me. You@re the one who@s leaving. Maybe you@ve gotten what you wanted out of this. You proved to yourself that you could commit to something. Well, a commitment lasts more than two days. They notice everyone staring at them and lower their voic

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You think you@ve got me all figured out.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe you can only commit to one thing at a time. I guess we know what your one thing is.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: You@re the one who can@t see past two months from now. I don@t think you can see this marriage in a week from now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I just don@t think there@ll be anything to see. (hurt)  You asked me to marry you. She twists the ring off her finger and holds it in her fi looking like she might throw it. Instead she drops her fist, turns around, and w away. James watches her for only a second before he turns and leaves.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sleeps in her old bed. In the other half of the r Linda Lue is packing to leave. The dog climbs in her suitcase and she out and sets him on the bed. It looks like she@s almost done. Her side the room now looks like a typical tacky motel room; no floral bedsprea picture of Loretta Lynn. Miranda opens her eyes.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Hey, you. I thought you were going to sleep through my departure.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: And miss the opportunity to see another piece of my life crumble away? Linda Lue looks concerned.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Do you want to tell me what happened with you and James? Mirada sits up.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I think the marriage just woke him up. We realized he didn@t want to be with me for the rest of his life. The wedding thing was a big mistake.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: (meaningful) And you didn@t have any second thoughts of your own.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: He@s the one who left me.  Linda Lue sits next to her on the bed.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Can I tell you a story?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: How many people die in this story?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Just one. When my Aunt Lydia was eighteen, she was engaged to marry Henry Esterbrook. However, the week before the wedding, Henry eloped with Marianna Fine. Aunt Lydia was so devastated she thought she@d rather be dead than be without Henry, so she decided to hang herself.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Has it occurred to you that this story is completely inappropriate for this situation?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: There@s more. Lydia went to the hardware store to buy a length of good strong rope, she couldn@t have weighed less than two hundred pounds, and the man that sold her that rope turned out to be her destiny. She married him that summer. My Uncle Ernie.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Which one of them dies?

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: My Uncle Ernie was bitten by a poison centipede later that same year. He died instantly. But that is beside the point and you know it. There is someone out there for everyone, and even if your head doesn@t know it, your heart does.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: So her heart led her to the hardware store.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Just like yours took to Memphis.  Remember the night I met you? I read your palm?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Yeah. But you didn@t read my heart line. Linda Lue gives her a knowing look.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: Sometimes people want to be surprised. Linda Lue reaches for Miranda@s hand. Miranda lets her ta Linda Lue examines it; we get the idea she may inventing the readin

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: See, it@s the same as before. You are not one to settle for the easiest thing - I think that@В®s true. A challenging relationship. . . that can be very romantic; to me that seemed like you and James, both of you so pig-headed.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: This isn@t helping.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: The important thing to know is to follow your heart. Don@t go against what it@s telling you, and don@t bury anything that ain@t dead. Miranda pulls her hand back.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Who@s going to die now? Linda Lue smiles.

dialogues.speaker: LINDA LUE
dialogues.text: No one that you don@t kill with your own two hands. You know, maybe next week would be a better time for me to leave.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No, honestly, I couldn@t stand you or Mr. Buster Dog another day. Go to Hollywood  and tell them who the hell you are. Linda Lue hugs her, then gets up and closes her suitcase.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda Lue and the dog are gone. Miranda sits cross-legged bed, her notebook open in front of her. We hear Pam Tillis passion singing @Maybe it was Memphis.@В® Miranda picks up a piece of paper that looks like her mar certificate. She folds it in half and cuts it into a heart shape. She unfo and cuts the heart into pieces with a jagged break. She positions them on a her notebook. There@s a knock at the door. Miranda opens it to find Kyl standing there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kyle leads Miranda out of the bar; she@s a little tipsy. pass a man ina cowboy hat standing on the sidewalk, singing for tips. Mi sings along with him.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I don@t know how productive this was

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Well, I@m having a pretty good time. Let@s go somewhere else. Wanna go to Graceland? Kyle@s just trying to get her into the car without incide

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Let@s get you home.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t get it.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: What.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: This whole thing. What@s the matter with me?

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Nothing. You are perfect.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No. There@s something wrong with me. Nobody wants me. Nobody cares about me. She@s really getting upset. Kyle wraps his arms around he holding her like a child.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (soothing) I care. I want you. She shakes her head no. He strokes her hair back off her

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: I care. I care about you. Miranda still doesn@t look like she@s herself.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Do you love me? Kyle loosens his hold on her; he has to protect himself n

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Miranda, don@t ask me that right now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: (persistent) Are you in love with me? Kyle pulls away from her altogether.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Yes. She pulls him to her slowly and kisses him, passionately. kisses her back, then breaks away gently and looks at her, quietly angry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don@t know what you@re doing, but stop it now. I won@t let you use me. She feels terrible; she was using him.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m sorry. Really.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Damn it, Miranda, what do you want me to do?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I don@t know. I want you to stay in love with me always, and I want you to get over me and be my friend forever.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Do you think I have some kind of choice? Miranda gives him a questioning look; she really doesn@t understand how he feels.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Sometimes you hear a song on the radio, and it@s just the song you wanted to hear right then. It@s like a gift. Then it@s over, and you@re just glad you heard it. You don@t want them to play it again right away. You@1ll hear that song again, or another one that@s just the perfect song when you hear it.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: And I@m like that song, the first one.

dialogues.speaker: KLYE
dialogues.text: No, you are nothing like that first one. You@re like if there was only one song in the world I could hear for the rest of my life, what song would that be. You@re that song.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Maybe the needle@s just stuck.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You@re the song that stays in my head all day, and I don@t even mind it. You@re my favorite song.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: For awhile, my favorite song was @Shadow Dancin@В®. It@s not anymore.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: (angry) You know what the problem with you is? You make it so hard for someone to care about you that once they do, there@s no turning back. It@s hot or cold, there@s no lukewarm. Kyle realizes something, sadly.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: That@s why James@1l come back Miranda won@t allow herself to hope for this.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: No he won@t. It@s o.k. This kind of thing happens to me all the time.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Miranda. What are you going to do when he comes back? Miranda sits down on the curb. Kyle sits next to her.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: I@m not going to be here. I@m going back home. This is the last thing Kyle wants to hear.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: This is your home.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Do you know how hard it was to leave New York? I had wanted to do it for years and  then my father died, and I just did it, left everything behind. I think I thought I could pay him back, for giving up his dream. Now I know he would@ve given it up sooner or later anyway. When you think you have a dream, all it does is give you hope that you can have something good, then you find out you can never have that. Maybe it wasn@t even there to be had.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: Don@t think that. You can@t live your life thinking that.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Kyle, all the signs are pointing in the same direction. Away from Nashville. Away from country music. At some point, I have to pay attentions. I have to start again.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You could do that here. You didn@t come here because of your father. You came here to write songs.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Saying you@re going to do something and actually doing it are two different things.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You have them inside you. What if you go to New York and you never get them out?

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Don@t make me feel any worse. This is all I have left. Kyle shakes his head, disagreeing.

dialogues.speaker: KYLE
dialogues.text: You still have everything that matters. She doesn@t answer. They sit side by side, watching traff by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It@s early in the morning. James comes out to his truck, a bag in it, and gets in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda, carrying her guitar and suitcase, buys a bus tic

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We see the Greyhound travelling down the highway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sits by a window, staring out. She reaches into h backpack, pulls out her walkman, and puts on the headphones.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A different highway. We see James in his truck, heading o Nashville ina different direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda fumbles through her backpack until she finds what looking for; a Bon Jovi cassette. She takes the tape out of its c pops it in her walkman. She presses play. We hear what she hears, but it Bon Jovi. It@s country music - her father singing one of his songs. is startled. She quickly hit stop, taking out the tape to look at it. Verifying what it is, she puts it back in her walkman and hits play.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James is driving, absently singing @Bad MedicineВ® to him

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda stares out the window, the tape still going in he walkman. We hear what@s on the tape - now it@s a letter from her father.

dialogues.speaker: VOICE ON TAPE
dialogues.text: that one was your favorite when you were two, you probably don@t remember. And that concludes the musical portion of our program. I hope they@re teaching you how to skin rattlesnakes at that camp, I@ve been setting snake traps all over the yard. I used Ding-Dongs for bait. I expect to have about thirty-seven by the time you come home. So don@t worry about me, I@m doing fine without you. I@1l miss you now, and you can miss me when you get home. That way I@ll be there. Chin up. That@s the end of the tape. Miranda listens to the silenc raises her chin, then lowers it and gives into her tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James has picked up a hitchhiker, and old man who listens while James rambles on.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: thinks she knows everything about me. Probably thinks I decided to leave because of her, like the world revolves around her . . . she thought she had me with that marriage thing . . . I might have better things to do with the rest of my life He trails off.

dialogues.speaker: HITCHHIKER
dialogues.text: Like what? James looks at the old man, startled.

dialogues.speaker: EST. TRUCK STOP
dialogues.text: The Greyhound is stopped at the truck stop. Miranda gets puts on her sunglasses and looks around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James pulls over and lets the hitchhiker out at a gas sta old man waves as the truck pulls back onto the highway. James dr the same direction as before for about ten seconds, then pulls a U heads back toward Nashville.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda sits in a booth in the coffee shop, looking out t as her bus pulls away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James goes through a dresser, opening and closing drawers They@re all empty. He goes into the kitchen and finds a house key on table.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Miranda has fallen asleep on the table. The waitress come touches her arm. Miranda raises her head and squints at her.

dialogues.speaker: WAITRESS
dialogues.text: You@ve been asleep for an hour. IT@ve been watching your stuff, but my shift@В®s over now.

dialogues.speaker: MIRANDA
dialogues.text: Thanks. The waitress fills her coffee cup. Miranda looks down at table. Her notebook is open; the page is filled with words. She look them, as if for the first time. She doesn@t seem sure if she likes what s

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: James comes into the caf@ and finds Lucy and Nick@s engag party in progress. A singer onstage dedicates a song to the happy who sit ata table near the back. James looks around for Miranda and, seeing her, goes over to Lucy and Nick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is Miranda here?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: No, honey, I@m sorry. Lucy doesn@t want to have to tell him

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: She told me she was going back to New York. This is a blow, but James still has hope.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: (urgent) When?

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: She left this morning. James deflates, his hope gone.

dialogues.speaker: LUCY
dialogues.text: Honey, why don@t you sit down. I@ll get you some champagne. James shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Beer. Lucy nods and gets up. James sits down next to Nick.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
dialogues.text: Congratulations.

dialogues.speaker: NICK
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: JAMES
